support_summary: AMFR (gp78) physically binds ATXN3 to coordinate ERAD (Co-IP evidence)

functions.cellular_process: Ubiquitin-dependent protein quality control at the ER
functions.effect_description: ATXN3 associates with AMFR (gp78) to edit ubiquitin chains on misfolded proteins, ensuring they are properly processed for proteasomal degradation rather than forming toxic aggregates.
biological_consequence: ATXN3 binds AMFR/gp78 -> Localization to ERAD sites -> Deubiquitination of gp78-tagged substrates -> Prevention of substrate aggregation -> Enhanced proteasomal turnover
specific_effects: Increases the degradation rate of gp78 substrates like SOD1
Reduces the formation of mutant protein aggregates in the ER/cytosol
gp78 promotes ATXN3 ubiquitination at K48-linked chains

evidence.paper_title: Gp78, an ER associated E3, promotes SOD1 and ataxin-3 degradation
evidence.relevant_quote: Here, we show that gp78 interacts with both SOD1 and ataxin-3. Overexpression of gp78 promotes the ubiquitination and degradation of these two proteins, whereas knockdown of gp78 stabilizes them.

mechanism_correction: ATXN3 directly interacts with the E3 ubiquitin ligase AMFR (gp78). While gp78 can target ATXN3 for polyubiquitination and degradation (acting as an upstream regulator), ATXN3 also functions as a downstream effector that binds gp78 to facilitate the deubiquitination and processing of other gp78 substrates (like SOD1 or misfolded CFTR) during ERAD. This interaction is mediated by the Josephin domain of ATXN3 and the N-terminal region of gp78.
mechanism: Ubiquitin-dependent protein quality control at the ER
effect: ATXN3 associates with AMFR (gp78) to edit ubiquitin chains on misfolded proteins, ensuring they are properly processed for proteasomal degradation rather than forming toxic aggregates.
summary: ATXN3 activates AMFR to modulate er-associated degradation (erad).
